options: Take no action - the nurse's social media is private and only visible to her friends
Email the ward sister informing her of your concerns
Report the post on social media
Tell the nurse immediately and ensure she removes the post, then discuss this with your supervisor
Tell the ward sister immediately
questions:
You see on social media that a nurse you work with has uploaded a photo of herself at work with patient information identifiable in the background. Several colleagues on the ward have left positive comments on the post.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes:
Tell the nurse immediately and ensure she removes the post, then discuss this with your supervisor is the best option. It is most important that the post is immediately taken down. It is also important to discuss this as it may be that an update on the appropriate use of social media would be helpful for the ward.

Tell the ward sister immediately is the next most appropriate action. This ensures fast action, though less immediate than speaking to the nurse directly. It also ensures a wider conversation about the appropriate use of social media is had.

Email the ward sister informing her of your concerns is less appropriate as the email may not be seen for some time, meaning the post containing sensitive information will remain on social media.

Report the post on social media is less appropriate. This should lead to the post being deleted but this may not happen for some time and the nurse might not be informed why what she posted is inappropriate. Appropriate channels need to be followed in the workplace to ensure this does not happen again.

Take no action - the nurse's social media is private and only visible to her friends is the least appropriate option. The post contains patient-identifiable information and it is a breach of patient confidentiality for the nurse to post this on her social media.

title: GMC: social media
body:
The GMC has produced detailed guidance on the use of social media.

One of the key passages discusses anonymity online:


17. If you identify yourself as a doctor in publicly accessible social media, you should also identify yourself by name. Any material written by authors who represent themselves as doctors is likely to be taken on trust and may reasonably be taken to represent the views of the profession more widely.§

18. You should also be aware that content uploaded anonymously can, in many cases, be traced back to its point of origin.

Please see the link for more details.

options: Report his behaviour to the GMC
Fill in an anonymous questionnaire about the quality of teaching at your hospital
Speak to your registrar about your concerns
Remind him that it is part of the job to help to train others
Report him to your consultant
Ask for support from someone more senior
Complain to the Foundation School
Do nothing
questions:
You are a junior doctor working in gastroenterology. The job is very busy, as a result you need a lot of support from your colleagues. The registrar has made it quite clear to you that he does not believe in teaching others. He never tries to help you when you have questions or provide any supervision, and even told the medical students on your ward that 'teaching is not part of my job description'. What do you do?

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
As with all scenarios in the MSRA regarding a dispute with colleagues, the top choice answer is to try and deal with the person in question directly. Having a conversation about your concerns regarding feeling unsupported and needing advice may help him to understand the difficult position you are in and hopefully he will change his ways. The GMC Good Medical Practice (2013) states that doctors have a responsibility to train and support others and so politely reminding him of this will support your claim.

The most immediate problem in this situation is the potential compromise of patient safety. If you feel like you need support and are not getting it from your immediate senior (i.e. your registrar) you are within your rights to ask your consultant for help.

Filling in a survey may not change very much for a long time if at all, therefore your will continue to struggle. Also by not talking to the doctor in question directly, the situation may never be resolved. Reporting him to the GMC or the Foundation School in the first instance is inappropriate when it could be resolved at ground level with far more ease. If you speak with him and the situation remains the same your next step up will be your consultant but again you should not do this before trying to resolve the situation yourself.

title: GMC Guidance: Teaching, training and assessing
body:
All medical professionals
  • Clinical and professional skills are largely developed through on-the-job training during placements.
  • All doctors should model professionalism when interacting with patients, colleagues, and learners.
  • If you’re involved in workplace teaching, you must demonstrate effective teaching practices, including respect for diversity and reasonable adjustments for disabilities, without compromising safety or standards.

Medical professionals with teaching leadership roles
  • Ensure teaching is delivered by suitably skilled professionals.
  • Maintain adequate staffing across disciplines to support education and supervision.
  • Use systems to identify and document the learning needs of trainees and locums.
  • Create inclusive learning environments and make reasonable adjustments under the Equality Act 2010.
  • Support ongoing development for trainers and ensure regular feedback and appraisal systems are in place.
concept: One of the requirements outlined in Duties of a Doctor is to train and support others therefore to not do so would be wrong

options: Explain that there has been a delay in the ultrasound department
Book an ultrasound scan and cancel the CT
Promise that the scan will happen today
Apologise to the patient
Explain what has happened to the patient
Ask her if she would like to file a complaint
Apologise to the radiology department
Suggest that she discusses this with the consultant
questions:
You are a junior doctor working in colorectal surgery. You have been on-call over the weekend and booked a patient in for a scan for Monday morning and told her to come back in for it. On Monday morning the patient arrives, and you realise that you have ordered the wrong scan (a CT scan when you should have ordered an ultrasound). What do you do?

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
The GMC recommend the following when things go wrong: offering an apology to the patient, putting the situation right (in this case, booking the correct scan) and explaining what has happened and the short and long-term implications of the mistake.

Telling the patient that there has been a delay in the ultrasound department is a lie. You should also never make a promise to a patient, as you cannot guarantee that a scan will happen when you say it will for a number of reasons. If it then did not happen, the patient will be even more annoyed. If it seems likely that the patient wants to file a complaint then explaining the process would be appropriate, but asking if she would like to file a complaint in the first instance is unnecessary. Another valid option would be to apologise to the radiology department, however the other choices are more appropriate when comparing to the GMC guidance.

title: Duty of candour
body:
All healthcare professionals must be honest when something has gone wrong. They must:
  • Tell the patient when something has gone wrong
  • Apologise to the patient (or carer or family member where appropriate)
  • Offer an appropriate resolution
  • Explain the potential short and long-term effects of the error

Important to note:
  • Saying sorry is not an admission of legal liability
  • The patient has a right to receive an apology from 'the most appropriate team member' - this will usually be the lead or accountable clinician
  • The process for reporting adverse incidents and near misses varies between different health organisations: you must follow your own organisations policy
  • The National Report d scheme
concept: When a mistake has occurred, you should apologise, explain what has happened and rectify the situation

options: Suggest to the patient that she asks her current partner to come with her to get 'checked out' at the local GUM clinic without telling him that she has Chlamydia, if she finds this easier
Give her a tablet of azithromycin to give to her partner
Treat her and explore the reasons why she does not want to tell her previous or current partner
Treat her but tell her she risk infertility through re-infection if her partner is not treated
Refuse to treat her if she doesn't give you any details
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor working at the local genitourinary medicine clinic. A 16-year-old female patient is found to have Chlamydia. When she is called back in she refuses to give details of her previous or current partner.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
A key concept here is to treat her regardless of whether she 'cooperates' and gives you the names of her previous partners. Refusing to treat her is blackmail and clearly unacceptable.

The best response is to explore why she doesn't want to tell her previous or current partners. This may lead to a discussion where you are able to allay her fears. The second approach, whilst likely to represent a factual statement, is less likely to get to the bottom of the problem.

If she feels she cannot face telling anyone then it would be worthwhile recommending that she suggests to her current partner that they go for a 'check up'. This would at least ensure the current partner is treated, although it would not deal with the former partner.

Refusing to treat her is a bad option as it is denying a patient medical care, as well as being a form of blackmail.

Giving her a tablet of azithromycin to give her partner is the worst option. You have no information regarding his medical history or allergies.

options: Ask one of the female members of staff to hold her down whilst you take blood
Put her on the observation ward
Discharge her if she refuses treatment
Advise her how important it is that you perform blood tests
Offer to use some EMLA cream
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor working in the Emergency Department. A 19-year-old female is admitted with abdominal pain. Her observations are stable and she seems to have 'voluntary' guarding on examination of her abdomen. She refuses to have blood saying she has a phobia of needles.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This scenario looks at whether you can adopt a sympathetic approach when dealing with patients.

The best option is to explain to the patient why it is important that you perform blood tests.

As the patient does not seem to be seriously ill it is acceptable to wait 30 minutes for the EMLA cream to work before taking bloods. Changing your usual management by not performing bloods is not good practice. Refusing treatment for any reason is not a reason to discharge a patient. Holding the patient down in such a situation would constitute assault.

options: Ensure the patient has access to a fertility specialist
Continue to oversee the care of this patient and her request
Explain that you don't discuss terminations of pregnancy due to personal beliefts
Explain that the patient has the right to see another doctor
Perform the necessary investigations and book her into the abortion clinic yourself
Refuse to see this patient again
Ensure the patient has access to a relevant healthcare professional
Inform the GMC of your conscientious objections
questions:
You are a junior doctor working in a GP practice. Your next patient is an 18-year-old pregnant female. She approaches you to discuss the possibility of a termination of her pregnancy. Due to your religion, you conscientiously object to abortion. What do you do?

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
The GMC Good Medical Practice contains specific guidelines for what to do when your beliefs become compromised:


Patients have a right to information about their condition and the options open to them. If you have a conscientious objection to a treatment or procedure that may be clinically appropriate for the patient, you must do the following.
  • Tell the patient that you do not provide the particular treatment or procedure, being careful not to cause distress. You may wish to mention the reason for your objection, but you must be careful not to imply any judgement of the patient.
  • Tell the patient that they have a right to discuss their condition and the options for treatment (including the option that you object to) with another practitioner who does not hold the same objection as you and can advise them about the treatment or procedure you object to.
  • Make sure that the patient has enough information to arrange to see another doctor who does not hold the same objection as you.

Even if you were involved in this patient's care, the patient would not require access to a fertility specialist, hence why this is an incorrect answer. When you have a conscientious objection to a procedure, you do not have to continue to oversee her care or perform investigations and book her in for the abortion (this responsibility you are passing to a colleague). You should not refuse to see the patient again as this is unprofessional and you should not allow your views to compromise patient care. The GMC do not need to be informed of your conscientious objections.

title: General Medical Council: duties of a doctor
body:
Make the care of your patient your first concern

Protect and promote the health of patients and the public
  • Provide a good standard of practice and care
  • Keep your professional knowledge and skills up to date
  • Recognise and work within the limits of your competence
  • Work with colleagues in the ways that best serve patients' interests

Treat patients as individuals and respect their dignity
  • Treat patients politely and considerately
  • Respect patients' right to confidentiality

Work in partnership with patients
  • Listen to patients and respond to their concerns and preferences
  • Give patients the information they want or need in a way they can understand
  • Respect patients' right to reach decisions with you about their treatment and care
  • Support patients in caring for themselves to improve and maintain their health

Be honest and open and act with integrity
  • Act without delay if you have good reason to believe that you or a colleague may be putting patients at risk
  • Never discriminate unfairly against patients or colleagues
  • Never abuse your patients' trust in you or the public's trust in the profession.
concept: An alternative doctor should be sought if you conscientiously object to abortion so that care is not compromised

options: Suggest to the doctor that it is not appropriate to talk about such things in a public space
Phone your medical indemnity provider for advice
Ask the most senior doctor present on the night out to intervene
Leave the table and report the matter to the doctors consultant in the morning
Go back to the hospital and apologise to the patient
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor night on a night out with a number of other doctors from your ward. During the meal the F2 doctor starts telling a story about how he accidentally punctured the femoral artery whilst attempting a femoral stab on an intravenous drug user who had poor venous access. He jokes that he made a real mess of it and he should have let the druggie do it himself. Whilst he is talking to your table other diners in the restaurant may be able to hear. At no point does he use any patient identifiable information.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Lets look at two extremes
  • Two doctors discuss relevant clinical information about a patient in a non-identifiable manner in a private place outside of work: most people would agree this is acceptable
  • Doctors discuss non-clinical information about a patient in an identifiable manner in a public place: most people would agree this is completely unacceptable.

Like most questions this is somewhere in between and requires the application of judgement. The doctor is in essence joking about making a mistake on what is clearly a night-out. This is not the most professional way to behave and may in a small way erode the confidence of the public in the profession. It is therefore appropriate to voice your concerns to the doctor. As this is such a core part of GMC guidance you should do it yourself rather than asking another, albeit more senior, doctor to do it for you.

There is no harm in phoning your medical indemnity provider but this is a matter of professionalism rather than a medicolegal problem.

Leaving the table does not address the problem and informing the doctors consultant about an apparent error of judgement does not seem appropriate.

options: Advise the patient of what has happened, apologise, review his rash and change his antibiotics
Advise the patient of what has happened, review his rash, change his antibiotics and suggest that he lodges a formal complaint
Continue cotrimoxazole as the patient has not had an anaphylactic reaction and prescribe an antihistamine for his rash
Cross off the cotrimoxazole and prescribe a different antibiotic alongside an antihistamine for the patient's rash
Review the patient, advise him that his rash may be secondary to his antibiotics and change his antibiotic treatment
questions:
You are working on a general medical ward when the pharmacist approaches you. They were reviewing the ward drug charts when they noticed that one man has received cotrimoxazole for a urinary tract infection, despite it being documented that he is allergic to trimethoprim. You remember that he had complained of a rash earlier on the ward round.

You are aware that the patient has been generally unhappy with his stay and already plans to lodge complaints about the noise on the ward and the food he has been given.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes:
In this scenario, a patient has been incorrectly prescribed antibiotics, despite a documented allergy, and these antibiotics have been given. These are likely the cause of this patient's rash. This question relates to duty of candour; in Good Medical Practice (2013), the GMC state clearly that healthcare professionals must be clear with a patient when something goes wrong. This includes telling the patient what has gone wrong, apologising and offering an appropriate remedy. This guidance still stands even if the patient has not come to harm. The fact that this patient is already planning to put in a complaint is irrelevant and certainly not a reason to withhold information. The most appropriate option is therefore to advise the patient of what has happened, apologise, review his rash and change his antibiotics.

Advise the patient of what has happened, review his rash, change his antibiotics, and suggest that he lodges a formal complaint is the next best option. It involves reviewing the patient, admitting the mistake and changing the antibiotics. However, in this scenario, the doctor does not apologise, and instead directs the patient directly to the route of a formal complaint. Part of duty of candour is apologising for mistakes. It may be possible to solve this issue on the ward without going towards the formal complaint system.


Review the patient, advise him that his rash may be secondary to his antibiotics, and change his antibiotic treatment is a safe option as it involves reviewing the patient and changing his antibiotics. However, it fails to take into account duty of candour. The doctor has not admitted that incorrect antibiotics were given and instead provides a generic suggestion for the rash that does not involve the team's mistake.

Cross off the cotrimoxazole and prescribe a different antibiotic alongside an antihistamine for the patient's rash deals with the immediate problem of the patient being prescribed a drug to which he is allergic, although it does not involve reviewing the patient and ensuring he has not suffered further adverse effects. Whilst in a patient who is already complaining about care it may be tempting to avoid mentioning mistakes, this clearly goes against duty of candour. The patient should be informed of the mistake and an apology should be offered.

Continue cotrimoxazole as the patient has not had an anaphylactic reaction and prescribe an antihistamine for his rash is the worst option. This answer is poor both in terms of duty of candour, as the mistake is not admitted to the patient, but also in terms of patient safety. It involves not reviewing the patient and continuing a medication that is, at best, causing an uncomfortable rash, and may cause further adverse symptoms.

questions:
You are a ST1 in General Practice. You are seeing a patient that you have known for the past 3 months who has disabling rheumatoid arthritis. At the end of the consultation she gives you a box of chocolates.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This scenario looks at whether you can apply judgement rather than answer in a knee jerk way.

The relevant GMC guidance is found in Good Medical Practice:

72. You must be honest and open in any financial arrangements with patients. In particular:
a. you must inform patients about your fees and charges, wherever possible before asking for their consent to treatment
b. you must not exploit patients' vulnerability or lack of medical knowledge when making charges for treatment or services
c. you must not encourage patients to give, lend or bequeath money or gifts that will directly or indirectly benefit you
d. you must not put pressure on patients or their families to make donations to other people or organisations
e. you must not put pressure on patients to accept private treatment
f. if you charge fees, you must tell patients if any part of the fee goes to another healthcare professional.


A patient giving you a box of chocolates is a perfectly reasonable way for them to express thanks. There is no need to register this, given the relatively small size of the gift. Declining the gift will probably come across as odd and rude.

Asking the patient to give an equivalent amount to charity may seem like a nice gesture but monetarises the offering. This may also conflict with the GMC guidance in Good Medical Practice, 72(d), reproduced above.

Telling the patient off is even worse.

questions:
You are working in the emergency department and a female patient presents with a knife wound to her upper chest. She tells you that she got in a fight in the middle of town over some money that she owed. The man she was arguing with pulled a knife on her. This story is corroborated by the paramedics.

Fortunately, the wound is superficial, and you have no concerns about any bony injury. You are able to close it and treat her with a tetanus booster.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
This question assesses your understanding of the GMC guidelines surrounding knife and gun-related injuries. (See http://www.gmc-uk.org/guidance/ethicalguidance/28437.asp) Although the wound might be superficial, the GMC advises that any wound obtained in such a manner should be reported to the police. (option 2) It would obviously be a high priority to ensure that there are no other vulnerable adults or children at risk (option 1).

Although the story is one of a fight over money owed, it is important that as the patients advocate you make her feels safe and give her the option to disclose if this is actually a case of domestic violence (option 5).

Option 3 may be a reasonable thing to do, but it is not as high a priority as the above. The question does not suggest that the patient is at all threatening so you would not need to call the police (option 4).

You should not ask a nurse to take responsibility for the discharge (option 6). At this point in time, there is no need to involve the safeguarding officer (option 7). Although in practice you may ask a senior (option 8), in this situation you are being asked what is the best option; which would be you managing the patient independently as far as you are able.
